\"Amongst these birds were those which in India they call Dod-aersen (being a kind of very big goose); these birds are unable to fly, and instead of wings, they merely have a few small pins, yet they can run very swiftly.\"
\"Striding bipedal locomotion has evolved independently in two vertebrate lineages, archosaurs and primates, and is represented today by humans and birds.\"

Contrary to popular belief, dodos were not clumsy creatures. Rather, the flightless birds were adept at transversing their rocky, dense Mauritius island. Historical accounts from sailors claimed that dodos \"can run very swiftly\" (Cheke 2004). What factors contribute to this surprising speed?

While humans stand up straight, dodos (and other birds) do not. In fact, the dodo\'s femur is \"relatively horizontal\" in position (Claessens). Imagine a sprinter just before a race begins; their stance is already at a crouch, ready to transition into a sprint.\n\n\t\tSmaller birds tend to have higher degrees of crouch, \"allowing them to maintain ground contact with the feet for longer durations (which increases stability), allowing them to make longer relative strides, and allowing them to transition to an aerial run at faster relative speeds\" (Bishop et al.).

If you\'ve seen a picture of a dodo, you\'ve probably noticed its stubby wings. Although flightless, dodo wings had \"well-developed muscle insertions\" and \"were not entirely vestigial\"; instead, they were probably used for balance and/or display, similarly to extant (living) columbids (Claessens).\n\n\t\tBut if the dodo is similar to flying extant columbids, you ask, why can\'t it fly? The simple answer is that it probably did not need to. Until Mauritius was discovered, the dodo was thriving on the rocky and vegetation-dense island, and its shortened wing meant that upon extending its elbow for balance, the wing would not drag on the ground (Claessens).

Dodos enjoyed \"strong, robust hind limbs\" to offset its increased body weight. These limbs also served to improve agility on the island of Mauritius, which supposedly had some open \"palm savanna\" but was otherwise covered by forest (Cheke 2010, Claessens).

The dodo is a fascinating creature of study. External characteristics like its stubby wings and round body not only make it endearing in media, but actually help contribute to a body well-suited to flightless living. Meanwhile, internal characteristics like leg composition and stance also do their part, providing an ongoing source of research and discovery.\n
Your cute dodo is safe in its cave. Whew!

The purpose of the app is for the maker to learn Java, IntelliJ and Android Studio, and to explore the differences in bipedal locomotion in the dodo bird and the human male adult.

In this app, the user picks a dodo with particular mass, inputs distances, and picks sailor health. Dodo and sailor speeds are calculated from mass and health respectively. A simple linear-pathed hunt ensues, and whoever reaches the dodo\'s cave first survives.

All calculations are based on Blanco's research into determining the maximum running speed of mammals and large birds (2003, 2005). 

		Human max speed (11 m/s) was observed from Blanco (2003) and adjusted based on a simplified range of health. 

		Dodo speed was calculated by combining two of Blanco's formulas: Formula A takes mass and various other inputs to produce limb effective length variation, while Formula B takes various inputs to produce velocity. 

		As you can tell, I needed to find: 1) the exact values of the "various inputs" for each formula, and 2) some sort of mathematical relationship between Formula A's limb effective length variation and Formula B's velocity in order to connect mass to velocity. 

		For all but one of the "various inputs", I borrowed Blanco's values (I will not go over them here). The missing input was duty factor. I ended up borrowing the kiwi bird's duty factor. My reasoning was that dodo hind leg proportion (Claessens 2015) is similar to the kiwi's (Gatesy 1997), and that "Two animals making dynamically similar movements would have equal relative stride lengths and equal duty factors" (Alexander, 2004). 

		For 2), I played with many ideas and saw if any stuck. I finally decided to take the mass and velocity of a bird in Blanco's study, and work my way back to figure out if there was any simple mathematical relationship between Formulas A and B. Unfortunately, Blanco did not apply his method to the kiwi bird. Fortunately, the kiwi has a similar duty factor to Rhea americana, which Blanco did study (Abourachid & Renous 2000). So I used Blanco's 2005 rhea results, found a rough linear relationship, and applied my findings to the dodo.

Despite being much shorter than the typical human male, the dodo boasts impressive max speeds. Firsthand accounts from sailors even called them swift (Cheke). 

		This is actually expected; for their size, birds already tend to be faster than humans due partly to their greater degree of crouch.

		The dodo may have been well adapted to being flightless, although it did eventually go extinct from a debated combination of sailor hunters and invasive species predators.

When working backwards to establish a mathematical relationship between Formulas A and B, I only had 3 Rhea sample points. I assumed the relationship was linear but it could have been more complex. 

		The 3 Rhea sample points I used were taken from the greatest, lowest, and mean values of rhea body mass and speed. 

		I assumed for simplicity that the lowest body mass corresponded with lowest speed since that is a general trend (Bishop 2018) but this may not have been exactly the case. 

		Smaller birds (like the dodo compared to the rhea) tend to higher degrees of crouch which may translate to greater speed for their size, so it may have been even faster than the rhea at the inputted mass (Gatesby). 

		Dodo structure is not like the rhea's; you can observe the rhea's thinner pointier beak and relatively large wings for a flightless bird. The dodo instead had stubbier wings perhaps used for balance or display (Claessens 2015). 

		Pre-human Mauritius was actually rocky and had dense forests (Claessens 2015). 

		I did not consider bone strength. Claessens (2015) says "the strong, robust hind limbs would have been necessary to support the bulk of a large, terrestrial pigeon, but were equally suited for agile maneuverability"; this may have benefited the dodo when being hunted by sailors. 

		This is max speed! This is not the speed that a dodo or human can maintain for extended periods of time. I am assuming naively that in a hunt, dodos (who were not that scared of humans) are sprinting for their lives and hungry sailors are sprinting after them.
Looks like your sailor is no longer hungry...
